Fields.DialogueText: Almost in firing range and awaiting orders, Captain.
@BATTLE
Morganas still in proximity, Captain. They're damaged, but standing their ground for the time being. Awaiting your next order.
All right. On my mark. Ready?
One moment, Captain. I understand your haste, but this could be an opportunity.
Maury? An opportunity for what?
The Morganas always flee once they've taken enough damage. This makes taking notes on their behavior difficult.
You want to take notes... on the Morganas?
You'd be surprised to know what a little observation can glean. If we study them, maybe we can better understand their strategies.
Awaiting your orders, Captain.
One way or another, those Morganas will flee. You can either fire on her now and expedite the process, or allow me to take a few notes before you lay into her.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not taking any chances, Maury. We're going after her.
... Fine. But only for a few seconds, understand?
What observations could you possibly make from this distance?

Fields.DialogueText: ... So be it, Captain.
Thank you, Captain. That's all I need.
I assure you, my eyesight is quite impressive, Captain.
Captain! The Morganas are making a run for it.
She must have decided she didn't like her odds.
Well, isn't that just my luck...
We're ready to engage, Captain. Just give the word.
@BATTLE
Do you have a moment, Maury?
I can talk while I work. Go ahead, Captain.
How did you make that shot?
This vessel has fired multiple shots at the enemy. You're going to have to be more specific.
The last shot of the last battle. I was sure we would miss, but whatever instructions you gave the crew before firing seemed to work wonders.
It was just a simple equation.
A simple... equation?
Yes. Calculating for wind, ship speed, that sort of thing. I did it all in my head.

Fields.MenuText: I never guessed math could be so... helpful.
You're certainly the intellectual type, aren't you?
You're serious?!

Fields.DialogueText: You never knew math could be... forgive me if I sound impertinent, but how did you ever become captain, Captain?
I suppose? It's not something I've given much thought to.
Numbers never lie.
... I think I'm glad you're on my side, Maury.
Captain, I have a question for you. I'm curious about how you operate.
How I operate? All... right. Go ahead, Maury. What do you want to know?
I'll begin with a hypothetical. Assume we're facing an enemy with an inhuman amount of endurance.
An enemy that continues pushing back, no matter how many defeats she faces.
This is sounding somewhat familiar.
At what point would you decide that the accepted method dealing with this enemy might not be the best way of dealing with this enemy?
You think we're wasting our time with these constant Morgana battles?
The battles are necessary - I understand that. I'm just of the mind that battles alone might not be enough to end this war once and for all.
What would you suggest?
If I had an extended opportunity to observe one of the Morgana ships, I do think the information I could gather could help the long term war effort.

Fields.MenuText: I don't want to jeopardize the crew by getting too close to one of those Morganas, Maury. It isn't worth the risk.
Everything has a weakness. If we push the Morganas enough, eventually, they'll make mistakes.
Tracking one of the Morganas would be risky... but I can see the benefits such observation could give us.

Fields.DialogueText: But wouldn't you endanger more lives by not taking action?
At what cost, Captain? At the rate this war is going, we'll likely run out of steam before the Morganas do.
We could learn about their tactics, how they move, or even how they're capable of recovering so quickly.
*ALARM*
This is a fun conversation and all, but...
Morganas. Let's move.
@BATTLE
We're almost in range, Captain...
@BATTLE
You're always reading whenever I find you, Maury.
I want to make the most of every moment I can, Captain.
An interesting way of thinking... what book are you reading this time?
A physics textbook.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not surprised. That book looks a tad worn... have you had it long?
Just try not to get too lost in your reading, Maury. We are at war...
I was hoping it would be something a little less serious...

Fields.DialogueText: It's my sixth time reading through it. And yet, I find I learn new things each time I do.
Relax, Captain. I'm just as alert as you are.
Were you hoping to catch me reading a poem? I prefer my reading materials to be more logical in nature.
Do you have much of an interest in physics?
The issue isn't interest as much as time. I'm afraid my duties as captain keep my attention focused elsewhere.
Well then, it's a good thing you have me by your side, don't you think?
Heh. Of course, Maury.
Hello, Captain. Good timing!
@BATTLE
Maury?
She's not in her quarters. Where could she be?
Oh. Captain! Maury is on deck.
Is she? Thanks for the heads up.
Maury, what are you doing out here? And what's all of this equipment for?
Ah, hello, Captain! I'm charting weather patterns. I find such information to have an array of helpful uses.

Fields.MenuText: How is knowing the weather going to help us?
First physics, now this? You really have a wide range of interests, Maury.
Why didn't you invite me?

Fields.DialogueText: Incoming fog can be used to conceal our movement, for instance.
Knowledge always wins the day, Captain.
You find this sort of thing interesting? I'm so happy to hear so! I'll continue charting tomorrow at dawn - I'll be sure to wake you, so you can join me.
What's the weather looking like?
Nothing too interesting, at the moment. The currents are moving quickly, but the sky is as blue as can be.
Let's hope it stays that way...
Well... here we go again.
We're ready, Captain.
@BATTLE
Oof! Sorry, Captain. I didn't notice you were in front of me. I apologize for bumping into you.
It's okay. Why are you in such a rush? There aren't any Morganas nearby...
I... uh... I was on my way to see Maury.
What for?

Fields.MenuText: I'm sorry to intrude... but I'd really like to know why you're in such a rush.
You wouldn't be hiding anything from me... would you?
Tell me what has you so flustered. That's an order.

Fields.DialogueText: Maury offers... prayer services for those who are religious...
N-never, Captain. I just tend to keep my religious practices private... Maury holds prayer services for the crew.
I'm so sorry. I was going to visit Maury. She holds daily prayer services for the crew.
You're religious?
Yes, Captain. Episcopalian. I was going to say some prayers for my family...
Are they okay?
T-they... some of the Morganas...
Say no more. Go along, you don't want to be late.
This war has been nothing but a travesty so far, Captain.
You don't have to tell me that... the Morganas are more ruthless than anyone could have imagined...
I'm not talking about their barbarism. It's the effect they've had on the world.
I'm sorry, I don't follow...
Every nation, before the war, was on the cusp of great technological advancement.
And?
And this war has halted society's advancement. Now, all research is militaristic in nature. Think what could've been achieved without this meaningless war.

Fields.MenuText: The world wasn't in such a favorable state even before the Morganas showed up... war was happening, regardless.
War is inevitable...
The faster we destroy the Morganas, the faster we can return to advancing science.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe... but we've no way of knowing how long that war would have lasted.
Ultimately, I suppose that's true...
I suppose that is true, Captain.
Now... do you have some free time? I'd like to discuss some strategies with you.
Of course, Maury. I'd be happy to.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Here they come.
@BATTLE
I've heard word around the ship that you've been helping the crew...
Of course I've been helping them. I make sure everyone is aware of the weather and up to date on potential tactics we might employ in battle...
Maury.
Of course, I've also been doing my best to expand the knowledge of the crew members I interact with on a daily basis.
Maury.
Yes? Clearly, you're trying to get at something in particular.
I just didn't have you pegged as the religious type.
Oh? So, you've heard about my prayer services, then? Wait... why do I not seem like the religious type?

Fields.MenuText: Given your passion for science, I didn't see you going for a system of belief you couldn't rigorously test.
I just don't seeing you folding your hands in prayer. I would've thought that you would find it a waste of time...
I just hadn't heard you speak on the subject.

Fields.DialogueText: I would say it's rigorously tested every day.
I assure you - prayer is in no way as waste of time.
Ah, well, I do suppose that, around you, my mind is typically focused on other subjects.
Is my faith a problem, Captain?
No, of course not. I'm sure the chaplains on board appreciate your assistance. And the crew as well.
Good. Now... can we get back to work?
Heh, of course.
Maury? You look unusually pensive - even for you. Everything all right?
Of course. I've had a thought, but... well, obviously, it can wait until after the battle.
The battle?
Ah. Sorry - Morganas are incoming.
Of course they are. I haven't eaten in... doesn't matter. I'll meet you on the bridge.
@BATTLE
Now, then. Captain, I have a somewhat serious query for you.
Can it wait until after we're done eating?
I'm afraid not. It's something I must settle now.
All right then, Maury. What is it?
Do you think killing is necessary?
A bit of a heavy topic to have over a meal, don't you think?
Please answer the question, Captain. I'm curious.

Fields.MenuText: We're fighting an enemy that wishes us dead. Killing is the only way we're going to survive.
I try not to think about the lives we might take... such thinking can distract us from our duty.
I don't know... it never crossed my mind...

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sure that's true - I'm of the mind that, in matters such as these, there's often more than one solution to the problem. But I'm in no position to judge.
I can understand that. But I think it's worth considering.
You're too focused on the objective? I'm not surprised.
I've answered your question. Can I get back to eating?
Of course. Thank you for your honesty, Captain.
Captain on the bridge!
So I am. How close are the Morganas?
I'm afraid you can see for yourself.
@BATTLE
I'm about to host a prayer service, Captain. Would you like to accompany me?
Sure, Maury - I have a few free minutes.
Wonderful. Follow me.
Why do you do this for the crew? It's a pretty selfless thing to do.
War is stressful for everyone. If we allow the stress to continue to build, eventually, the crew's performance will suffer.
These prayer services offer a relief from the stress, a respite for the crew's spirits.

Fields.MenuText: What are your beliefs, Maury?
How did you manage to put these services together?
I'm still just surprised that you, of all people, would put together such a service.

Fields.DialogueText: That's a discussion for another time, Captain.
I coordinated with the chaplains on board. I think they were a little taken aback by my offer, but once I shared my beliefs with them, they were happy to work with me.
Didn't we discuss this already? My dedication to logic does not preclude me from having faith.
Here we are. Observe, pray if you feel called to do so.
Here they come, Captain.
@BATTLE
You know, you surprise me, Maury.
How's that, Captain?
You're so dedicated to studying...
I'm not sure why that would surprise you, at this point.
Let me finish. You're so dedicated to studying, but on the rare occasion you actually turn your attention from academia, you're actually...
Yes...?
A bit of a force to be reckoned with. When you're at your desk, you're orderly and a little staid. During battle, though, you're... well, you're pretty tough.
I am a warship first and foremost. If I became so focused on my studies that I neglected my duties, it would... create some problems.
I know I can grow obsessed with certain things if I don't watch myself, so I do my best to maintain as much balance as possible.
You're quite the multi-faceted Belle. Every time I think I've figured you out, I notice something new.
It's like the study of most subjects, really. The more you learn, the more you realize you do not know.
I think you're right on that count, Maury.
I'm glad you're here, Captain. We're not alone.
@BATTLE
Maury, are you drinking?
Captain, we all need to relax a little, every now and then.
You just didn't seem like much of a drinker, I suppose.
I don't imbibe very often. But I recognize that all work and no play makes Maury a real drag to be around.
What are you drinking? I'm curious.
It's cachaça, a type of sugarcane alcohol.
Sounds like the type of thing that would keep me up all night...
Well, it helps soothe my worries after a strenuous day. Would you like some?

Fields.MenuText: Sure, I could use a drink.
Maybe another time, I have work to do...
Only if you take it easy with the science, Maury.

Fields.DialogueText: Excellent. Let me pour you a glass.
That's too bad. But I understand the importance of work.
I can't make any promises on that front, Captain.
Ready to engage the enemy!
@BATTLE
Hmm...
What is it? Something bothering you?
Your diet, Captain.
I can't even eat without you trying to make calculations, can I? That's what you're doing, isn't it?
Your meal isn't balanced. A few changes to what you're eating could make a world of difference in your energy-level.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not concerned about what I'm putting in my mouth. The Morganas have my full attention.
Really? How would I fix my eating habits, Maury?
Should I eat the same things as you?

Fields.DialogueText: I understand that. But fighting an enemy requires a lot of energy. If you eat the right things, you'll have more endurance to fight.
It's a simple fix, Captain. Let me observe your habits for a few days and measure your portions. Then I'll come up with the perfect diet.
No, no, no. We require different portions. No body is the same.
You really never stop thinking, do you?
It's my job, Captain!
Morganas incoming, Captain.
@BATTLE
There are some more Morganas inbound.
Take them out.
We can't. The weather is making visibility an issue.
You can't get a shot on her?
Not from this distance, Captain.
If you'd allow me, Captain. I'd like to take point.

Fields.MenuText: Go ahead, Maury.
You might have the uncanny ability to make perfect shots in clear weather, but not when a storm is brewing.
Can you do it? Can you make the shot?

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Captain.
You think I don't know how to take the storm's variables into consideration? I assure you, Captain, I know what I'm doing.
Trust me.
I don't know what you think...
I'm going to tell you where to aim. I'm going to tell you when to fire. Understand?
... Okay.
Good. Aim like so...
Fire.
*BOOM*
Target hit.
That was... great work, Maury.
Brace yourself, Captain. They're almost in range.
@BATTLE
Captain, I'd like to discuss the war with you, and perhaps ask you for some personal input.
Of course, Maury. Please, have a seat.
Some time ago, we discussed killing. Do you remember?
I do. You want to continue that conversation?
In a sense. I still have some questions I want to ask.
Okay, Maury. Go ahead.
Assume we come across information that would guarantee our victory against the Morganas. We're in the midst of combat and that information will be destroyed if we don't act quickly.
What's the catch?
Should we go after the information, the Morganas will have the opportunity to destroy a civilian vessel. We can either obtain the information, or save the civilians.
What would you choose?

Fields.MenuText: I would save the civilians. Our duty is to protect the innocent.
If we don't get that information, we're putting the world at risk. It's for the greater good that those civilians die.

Fields.DialogueText: Really? Even if it means losing the war? You'd risk that?
But would you be able to sleep at night, knowing you could have saved them?
It's a lose-lose scenario, Maury. All we can do is hope we never face such a decision.
Maury?
You know, I'm a firm believer that there's no such thing as a lose-lose scenario. Because there are never just two options.
If you're willing to think outside of the box, chances are, there's another option you hadn't even considered.
Well, you didn't tell me I could have picked a third option!
I know, I know. I wanted to make an impression on you. Never forget to think outside of the box.
Well... I appreciate the advice, Maury.
Of course, Captain.
Enemy group inbound. Everybody ready?
@BATTLE
Only a few Morganas left. Maury, looks like those are on you again. They're too far...
Leave it to me. Everyone, fire on my mark.
Yes, ma'am.
Ready?
Fire.
*BOOM*
Target...
It missed...
I... missed?

Fields.MenuText: Move in closer and take the shot.
It's okay, Maury. Everyone, follow my lead. We can take them down. Fire another shot.
Don't stop. Keep firing.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Captain.
Roger that. You heard the Captain. Move in.
Will do. Everyone, resume fire.
There's no way... it's not possible... I took everything into account...
Maury? Did you lock yourself in my quarters?
I... how could I?
Maury. Open up.
Why are your books scattered around my quarters? What's going on?
I missed. I had a clear shot, we weren't under fire, and I missed. I never miss. I refuse to miss.

Fields.MenuText: It was one shot, Maury. Everyone makes mistakes...
Look, you were at the end of a rough fight, you weren't thinking clearly.
Refusing to miss doesn't make missing an impossibility.

Fields.DialogueText: Not me, Captain. I can't allow it. Could... could you leave me alone for a bit?
I need to make some calculations, Captain. Alone...
It was until that last battle. Can you give me some time to myself? I need to think...
It's going to be okay, Maury.
Maury, I need you to take a deep breath and get your head clear. Morganas are almost in range.
Yes, Captain. I'll be... I'm ready.
@BATTLE
I missed... again...
Maury, you're putting too much pressure on yourself. If you'll just relax, I promise, everything will be fine..
I-I... I'm not...

Fields.MenuText: I need you to focus, Maury. We have work we need to do, and I need you in the right headspace.
I'm ordering you to keep a cool head. We can't run this ship without you, Maury.
Snap out of it, or we'll be getting a new Belle. Do you understand?.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes... okay, Captain. I'll do my best, I promise...
Right, right, of course, Captain. I won't let you down, I won't let the crew down, I promise.
Comments like those really don't help the situation, Captain. And do you even understand how Belles work?
Just breathe for a few minutes, all right? Once you've calmed down, come find me on the bridge.
Yes, Captain...
Hang in there, Maury...
Maury?
Maury, whatever you're feeling, you can't let the crew pick up on it. Not before a battle.
You're right. Of course.
Look, we'll talk when the shooting stops.
@BATTLE
Maury...
I know why you're here, Captain.
You have to calm down, Maury.
Calm? What if those missed shots cost us the fight? What if the crew all died because of me?
You can't be...
Perfect? I have to be. If I'm not, the Morganas will take advantage of my failing, and that will be the end of everything.

Fields.MenuText: You need to understand that mistakes happen. And if you continuously beat yourself up over those mistakes, you're only making your situation worse.
You think everyone on this ship is perfect? We're not. That's why we have a crew, because together, we can overcome our weaknesses.
If you keep this up, it won't be the Morganas who are responsible for your ultimate failure.

Fields.DialogueText: ... I'll try to take what you said to heart...
... I suppose that much is true.
You...  may actually have a point. Thank you, Captain.
Are you going to be all right, Maury?
I... think so, Captain.
Let's end this one fast, people!
@BATTLE
We have a one last Morgana, headed this direction.
... Fire on my mark.
M-Maury? Are you sure? Captain?
You heard her.
... Okay. On your mark, Maury.
Now!
*BOOM*
That... that's a direct hit!
Whew...

Fields.MenuText: Good to have you back, Maury.
See? If you stay calm and collected, anything is possible...
A little relieved?

Fields.DialogueText: Just trying to do my job, Captain.
I think a little bit more went into that shot than just being calm and collected...
More than a little, Captain.
How about we break out the cachaça?
Nothing sounds better, Captain.
This might sound somewhat silly to you, Captain...
What is it, Maury?
More than calculations went into making that last shot.
What else was there? Luck?
No, not luck. I-I prayed. I cleared my head and prayed that my shot would be true.

Fields.MenuText: Well, you made the shot... you must be feeling pretty righteous, Maury.
So, what? You think God solved your shooting problem?
Maybe I should start praying for us to win the war...

Fields.DialogueText: It's not a matter of righteousness, Captain. But I do feel as if someone was listening to me.
I wouldn't put it past Him, certainly.
It might not be a bad use of your downtime.
Regardless of how it happened, I'm just happy you're back to your old self.
Perhaps a little more humble than my old self... but yes, I must say, I agree.
@BATTLE
Morganas almost in range. How're you feeling, Maury?
You ask like you know the answer.
Well... I'm optimistic, anyway.
@BATTLE
I know the perfect meal for you, Captain. Such a meal will make a world of difference on your energy level during battle.
Okay, Maury. What is it?
Pit-roasted pork with long rice.

Fields.MenuText: That's quite a mouthful. Why is that the meal that's perfect for me?
That's an awfully specific meal, Maury. I'm guessing you like it?
Sounds good, do we have any on board?

Fields.DialogueText: Trust me, it's perfect for everyone.
It's one of my favorite dishes. Nothing sates my hunger more.
I had some prepared earlier today. I'll go grab you a plate.
Wait a second...It's your favorite meal...
Correct.
If you wanted me to try something that you liked, you didn't have to lie to me.
I wasn't lying! I honestly believe it will help your energy level!
Sure you do.
Captain? Here they come.
@BATTLE
Am I interrupting? You seem lost in that book of yours.
I'm just reading through it... again.
How many times have you read this one?
This will be my tenth time.
You really love science, don't you?
I really do.
Hey... would you like me to give you a quick lesson?
A lesson in what?
In physics. I'll give you a basic introduction. Come on, it'll be fun.

Fields.MenuText: Sure thing, I could use the refresher. Go ahead, Maury.
If you think it'll be fun, then sure...
Maybe later...

Fields.DialogueText: Let's get started.
Trust me, Captain. It will open your mind.
I'll hold you to it.
We're almost in range, Captain.
@BATTLE
You know, Captain... I know the two of us have discussed some heavy topics recently.
Like the discussion about killing? And the mock scenario you made up?
Yes. I just wanted to tell you how much I appreciate you having those conversations with me. I love having the opportunity to discuss complex subjects with others.
I think I've even learned a few things from you, along the way.
How so?
I've always tried to keep an open mind, but even so, it can be difficult sometimes to understand other perspectives.
That's surprising to hear...
But hearing your perspectives, and why you have the beliefs you have, well, I think it's helped broaden my horizons.
Well... I'm happy to help in anyway I can, Maury.
I know you are. Thank you, Captain.
Of course, Maury.
@BATTLE
I don't mean to downplay the loss of life and all the injuries... but I think we've been improving over the last few battles. It's satisfying.
I'm glad to hear it. For what it's worth, I certainly think you're getting more impressive as you go.
You think so?
I do.
Well. Are you ready for a physics lesson, Captain?
Do I have much of a say in the matter?
I don't think so, no. In fact, I'm of the mind that I won't rest until you're able to calculate a gun's trajectory with the speed and confidence that I do on a daily basis.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I look forward to all time spent with you, Maury.
That's... going to take a while.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain... you're going to make me blush.
Well then, we best start as soon as possible.
We've got incoming, Maury. Are we ready?
I think you'll be satisfied, Captain.
